guide.title: Upgrade guide to MySQL 4.1.x
guide.abstract: The MySQL herd is proud to announce that MySQL 4.1 can now be found in Gentoo's unstable tree (~arch). As the team hopes that it soon will be able to stabilize this ebuild, here's an upgrade path for all willing testers.

chapter.title: Upgrading from old versions of MySQL

body.p: Users upgrading from an old version (<4.0.24) of MySQL will first have to install MySQL 4.0.25. If you are already running a current version, you can skip this section and continue with the next one.

chapter.title: Creating a backup of your current data

body.p: One of the most important tasks that every database administrator has to perfom is backing up data. Here we go:
Now a file named BACKUP_MYSQL_4.0.SQL should exist, which later can be used to recreate your data. The data is described in the MySQL dialect of SQL, the Structured Query Language.
Now would also be a good time to see if the backup you have created is working.

chapter.title: Upgrading from recent versions of MySQL

body.p: If you have skipped step #1, you now have to create a backup package (of the database server, not the data) of the currently installed version:
Now it's time to clean out the current version and all of its data:
body.pre: # /etc/init.d/mysql stop # emerge -C mysql # tar cjpvf ~/mysql.$(date +%F_%H-%M).tar.bz2 /etc/mysql/my.cnf /var/lib/mysql/ # ls -l ~/mysql.* # rm -rf /var/lib/mysql/ /var/log/mysql
body.note: Now two different backups should exist: The SQL one, which is portable between various versions of MySQL, and the other one that will allow you to quickly restore your database. This will be covered later in this doc in more detail.
body.p: After you got rid of your old MySQL installation, you can now install the new version. Note that revdep-rebuild is necessary for rebuilding packages linking against MySQL.
Now configure the newly installed version of MySQL and restart the daemon:
Finally you can import the backup you have created during step #2.
body.impo: The default /etc/mysql/my.cnf file sets binary logging (log-bin) by default. This will log every single transaction that modifies data. If run on a very large database (1GB for example), this could create extremely large files that take up disk space rather quickly. If you are low on space, disabling binary logging might be a good idea.
body.p: If you now restart your MySQL daemon and everything went as expected, you will have a fully working version of 4.1.x! :-)
If you encountered any problems during the upgrade process, please report them at our Bugzilla.

chapter.title: Recover the old installation of MySQL 4.0

body.p: If you are not happy with MySQL 4.1, it's possible to go back to MySQL 4.0.
body.pre: # /etc/init.d/mysql stop # emerge -C mysql # rm -rf /var/lib/mysql/ /var/log/mysql # emerge --usepkgonly "<mysql-4.1" # tar -xjpvf mysql.[tag] -C / # /etc/init.d/mysql start

body.p: Under certain conditions it's possible to directly upgrade to the next major version of MySQL. If you know what you're doing and think that applies to your case, here's a little trick that makes it possible to directly upgrade to MySQl 4.1.
body.pre: # quickpkg dev-db/mysql # /etc/init.d/mysql stop # tar -cjpvf ~/mysql.$(date +%F_%H-%M).tar.bz2 /etc/mysql/my.cnf /var/lib/mysql/ # ls -l ~/mysql.* # export MYSQL_STRAIGHT_UPGRADE=1 # emerge -av ">mysql-4.1" # unset MYSQL_STRAIGHT_UPGRADE # dispatch-conf # revdep-rebuild # /etc/init.d/mysql start # mysql_fix_privilege_tables --defaults-file=/etc/mysql/my.cnf \ -uroot --password='your_password' # mysql --database=mysql -uroot --password='your_password' < /tmp/new_pieces.sql # /etc/init.d/mysql restart # just to be sure
body.p: Good luck and if something fails, don't say we didn't warn you! ;-)
